thread.title_full: No smoke alarms in Brampton house fire where 3 died | Toronto Star

author: Hina Alam
title: No smoke alarms in Brampton house fire where 3 died
text:
There were no functioning smoke alarms in a Brampton home where fire killed three family members last week, the Ontario Fire Marshal’s office says. Amina Kapadia, 19, and her parents, Iftekhar Niazi, 48 and Jyoti Kapadia, 45, died on Feb. 14 in their house on Madison St., near Dixie Rd. and Williams Pkwy. The only survivor of the family is Zoya Kapadia, 8, who remains in hospital, where she was taken suffering third-degree burns and smoke inhalation.
RELATED STORY : 
Relatives, friends mourn family killed in Brampton house fire 
The cause of the fire is still under investigation, said Ontario Fire Marshal spokesperson Carol Gravelle.
  According to the Ontario Fire Code, homeowners must have smoke alarms on every storey and outside all sleeping areas.
Andrew von Holt, Brampton’s division chief of fire prevention, said the Kapadia-Niazi family was renting the home. 
Von Holt said Tuesday that it was too early to say whether charges would be laid over the lack of smoke alarms. 
“We’ll have to look at the evidence we’ve got before us and look at all that first,” he said.
Zoya was brought from hospital Sunday on a stretcher to say goodbye to her parents and sister at a funeral at Brampton Makki Masjid. 
RELATED STORY :
Mourners in 'shock' days after death of family in Brampton fire 
The girl was rescued by 19-year-old Sheldon Teague, who was visiting a friend in the downstairs apartment at the home when he smelled smoke. Using the flashlight on his friend’s phone, Teague made his way into the upstairs apartment, where he pulled Zoya to safety. 
Seven people were believed to be in the home at the time of the fire — three people in a basement apartment who escaped unharmed and four people in the upper levels of the home, according to the Office of the Fire Marshal.
